section.title: Introduction
section.para: By installing applications or adding your own builder files you can expand the object types that can be used in MMBase.

Active builders are stored in the builders directory of the MMbase configuration directory. New MMBase installations only contain the core builders. In order to add an object type, you need to add a builder xml, with the name objecttype.xml somewhere in the builders directory.

You can make use of subdirectories to divide your buidlers in groups for easier maintenance. Note that the MMBase core builders are located under core, and that the applications by default install new builders under applications.

section.title: Builder XML Format
section.para: A builder file uses the following general format:
section.programlisting: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!DOCTYPE builder PUBLIC "-//MMBase/DTD builder config 1.1//EN" "http://www.mmbase.org/dtd/builder_1_1.dtd"> <builder name="..." maintainer="..." version="..." extends="..."> <status>...</status> <classfile>...</classfile> <searchage>...</searchage> <names> <singular xml:lang="...">...</singular> ... <plural xml:lang="...">...</plural> ... </names> <descriptions> <description xml:lang="...">...</description> ... </descriptions> <properties> <property name="...">...</property> ... </properties> <fieldlist> <field> <descriptions> <description xml:lang="...">...</description> ... </descriptions> <gui> <guiname xml:lang="...">...</guiname> ... <guitype>...</guitype> </gui> <editor> <positions> <input>...</input> <list>...</list> <search>...</search> </positions> </editor> <db> <name>...</name> <type state="..." notnull="..." key="...">...</type> </db> </field> </fieldlist> </builder>
section.para: Most builders include less information than given here - since they can extend from each other, you only need to supply information that overrides the default, or when you add information such as fields.
The following sections explains the use and intention of each tag ind etail.

section.title: <builder>
section.para: The builder tag is the main tag. It's attributes define the builder's identity and place in the builder hierarchy. It is the parent of all other tags.

listitem.simpara: The name of the builder, which should currently be equal to the name of the builder file, without extension.

listitem.para: The maintainer of the builder. This attribute is mandatory, and should contain the name of the organsiation maintaining the builder. This is generally a domain name. For the core builders this value is mmbase.org

listitem.simpara: The version number of the builder

The name of a builder that this builder extends. If you do not specify a builder, you should fully describe the builder (include all tags). If you do specify a parent builder, you need only describe new or changed tags or attributes. The default builder that is extended is object.

section.title: <status>
section.para: The status tag determines whether a builder is active or not. Valid values are active and inactive.
You generally do not specify this tag unless you want to turn a builder off

section.title: <classfile>
section.para: The java class used by this buidler to administarte nodes of that builder type.
Specify this tag if you have custom behavuior defined for an object type.
The default value for a builder that extends the core builder object is org.mmbase.module.builders.Dummy.
The default value for a builder that extends the core relation buidler insrel is org.mmbase.module.corebuilders.InsRel.

section.title: <searchage>
section.para: The value given here is used be a number of generic editors, as a default value for the maximum age in days when searching for objects in MMBase.
Since this value is not available through the MMBase Bridge interface, this value is mostly used in older editors, that directly access the core system (such as SCAN).
The default value for a builder that extends the core builder object is 1000.

section.title: <names>
section.para: This section is used to supply gui (graphical user interface) names for the builder. The information is generally used in generic editors, as well as the default value for use in the editwizards.
You can include gui names for different languages. the system picks the correct name depending on its currently specified locale.

section.title: <singular>
section.para: A singular presentation of the builder object type, such as 'Person' or 'Company'.

listitem.simpara: The language for this name in ISO 639-1 format. The default value is en.

section.title: <plural>
section.para: A plural presentation of the builder object type, such as 'People' or 'Companies'.

listitem.simpara: The language for this name in ISO 639 format. The default value is en.

section.title: <descriptions>
section.para: This section is used to supply a description or help text for the builder. It may include information on the type of objects, specific behavior,and how it should be used.
You can include descriptions for different languages. the system picks the correct description depending on its currently specified locale.

section.title: <description>
section.para: A description of the builder object type.

listitem.simpara: The language for this description in ISO 639-1 format. The default value is en.

example.programlisting: <descriptions> <description xml:lang="en">Name and address information regarding contacts of our company.</description> <description xml:lang="nl">Naam and adres gegevns van contactpersonen van ons bedrijf.</description> </descriptions>

section.title: <properties>
section.para: A list of nam-value pairs, used by the java class specified in the classfile as configuration parameters. You normally only specify properties for objects with specific behavior (such as Images).

section.title: <property>
section.para: One single property name-value pair

listitem.simpara: The name of the property.

section.title: <descriptions>
section.para: This tag is used to supply a description or help text for the field. It may include information on the type of objects, specific behavior,and how it should be used. This description is used (among other places) in the editwizards.
You can include descriptions for different languages. The system picks the correct description depending on its currently specified locale.

section.title: <description>
section.para: A description of the field.

listitem.simpara: The language for this description in ISO 639-1 format. The default value is en.

example.programlisting: <descriptions> <description xml:lang="en">First name or initials of our contact.</description> <description xml:lang="nl">Voornaam of initialen van de contactpersoonen.</description> </descriptions>

section.title: <gui>
section.para: This section containsgui (graphical user interface) information for the field. The information is generally used in generic editors, as well as the default value for use in the editwizards.
This tag inlcudes gui names for different languages to represent a label for the field. The system picks the correct name depending on its currently specified locale.
It can also contain one guitype, which explains how the field should be rendered or edited.

section.title: <guiname>
section.para: A text to use as label for the field, such as 'First Name'.

listitem.simpara: The language for this label in ISO 639-1 format. The default value is en.

section.title: <guitype>
section.para: An identifier used to determine how a field should be rendered or edited. There are a number of predefined values. You can also add your own values, but you will have to add your own code to handle these new types.
Possible values for this field are:

listitem.simpara: A simple, one-line string of limited length, such as a title.
A text box, not generally limited in the amount of text that can be edited.
A numeric, integer value.
A date or time value. This value is represented internally by an integer number, representing the number of seconds since 1 january 1970.
A binary object representing an image.
A binary object, genmerally obtained from a file (i.e.e a Word document or PDF).
Specify this value if the field is a NODE field (see the db/type tag). If given, the system may use this data to create a browseable list of the objects in that builder whenever you edit this field

Specify this value if the field is a XML field (see the db/type tag). If given, the system may use this data to determine the XML dcoument type. The value mmxf can be used a macro and specifies a default 'richttext' xml doctype.

section.title: <editor>
section.para: Determines settings for this field when used in a generic editor.

section.title: <positions>
section.para: Lists the positions of a field in certain types of forms.

section.title: <edit>
section.para: Position of the field in an edit screen. -1 means the field cannot be edited.

section.title: <list>
section.para: Position of the field in an object list. -1 means the field will not occur in a list.

section.title: <search>
section.para: Position of the field in a search form. -1 means the field cannot be searched on.

section.title: <name>
section.para: The symbolic name of this field. The symbolic name is used to refer to the field in programming code or in a taglib or SCAN template. It is also used to map the field to a field in a database table.

section.title: <type>
section.para: the MMBASE type of the field. This determines, among other things, validation rules and the type of the field in the database.
Possible attributes are:

listitem.simpara: Either persistent, system or virtual.
A persistent or system field is stored in the database, a virtual field is generated live and not stored.
A system field cannot be altered except by the MMBase system.
Value can be true or false. If true, this field cannot be empty. This is not currently enforced except by the editwizards.
Value can be true or false. If true, this field must be unique.

section.para: Possible values are:

listitem.simpara: A text string.
An integer field.
A long (large integer) field.
A real field. Real is rather short - use DOUBLE if possible.
A double real field.
A reference to another object, internally represented as that object's number.
A binary field such as an image.
A field containing an xml document.

section.para: A full field example:

example.programlisting: <fieldlist> <field> <descriptions> <description xml:lang="en">First name or initials of our contact.</description> <description xml:lang="nl">Voornaam of initialen van de contactpersoonen.</description> </descriptions> <gui> <guiname xml:lang="en">First name</guiname> <guiname xml:lang="nl">Voornaam</guiname> <guitype>string</guitype> </gui> <editor> <positions> <input>4</input> <list>-1</list> <search>4</search> </positions> </editor> <db> <name>firstname</name> <type state="persistent" size="255" key="false" notnull="false">STRING</type> </db> </field> </fieldlist>
